current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To restrict the ability of the Federal Government to undermine privacy and encryption technology in
			 commercial products and in NIST computer security and encryption
			 standards.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The United States is the world leader in technology, encryption, and computer security.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
National Institute of Standards and
			 Technology

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, plays a vital role in
			 developing the tools that keep global electronic communications secure.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Information Assurance Directorate of the National Security Agency
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Information Assurance Directorate of the National Security Agency

text.#text: The United States Government, through the expert work of the

The United States Government should actively promote privacy and computer security.  Allegations
			 that entities within the United States Government seek to undermine the
			 security of en­cryp­tion standards or commercial products weaken privacy
			 and
			 erode trust in the United States Government and in products from the
			 United States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may take a serious toll on the United States economy.  The
			 Information Technology and Innovation Foundation has predicted that United
			 States companies may lose 10 percent of the cloud computing market to
			 overseas competitors due to surveillance and security concerns, a loss
			 that could amount to not less than $35,000,000,000 in lost sales by 2016.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:2/p:3

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is recognized around the world, but widespread adoption of the
			 robust encryption standards that

text.#text:
To promote privacy protection and restore trust in the encryption standards of the United States
			 and hardware and software from the United States, the United States
			 Government should be prohibited from undermining the security of the
			 United States technologies on which global commerce relies.

quote.#text: assure, to the maximum extent feasible

text.#text: by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
does not intentionally weaken, circumvent, undermine, or
			 create any mechanism through which any agency or office of the Federal
			 Government may bypass, the privacy, security, or encryption
			 protections included in any standard or guideline;

text.#text: that any agency or office described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 20 of the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20/ss:e
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20/ss:f
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20/ss:d

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may not
			 intentionally weaken, circumvent, undermine, or create any
			 mechanism through which any agency or office of the Federal Government may
			 bypass, the privacy, security, or encryption protections
			 included in any standard or guideline required under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20/ss:c/p:1
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20/ss:a
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:20/ss:b

text.#text: Each agency or office that the Institute consults with under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 22 of the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:22
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:22/ss:a/p:2

quote.#text: Computer System Security and Privacy Advisory Board under section 20(f)

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Information Security and Privacy Advisory Board
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Information Security and Privacy Advisory Board
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:21
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:22/ss:e/p:1

quote.#text: Computer System Security and Privacy Advisory Board

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Information Security and Privacy Advisory Board
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Information Security and Privacy Advisory Board
National Institute of Standards and Technology Act/s:21

header.#text: Security of computer hardware, computer software, and electronic devices

term.#tail: have the meaning given those terms in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 101(a) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act
			 of 1978
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978/s:101/ss:a

text.#text: means an individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, or corporation; and
does not include a foreign power or an agent of a foreign power;

term.#tail:
means any computer hardware, computer software, or electronic device that is made available to the
			 general public; and
means an element of the intelligence community specified in or designated under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 3(4) of
			 the National Security Act of
			 1947
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Security Act of 1947/s:3/p:4

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, an agency or department of the Federal Government may not
			 intercept any shipment of covered
			 products for the purpose of
			 intentionally introducing into the covered products a mechanism or device
			 that would allow an agency or department of the Federal Government to
			 circumvent the privacy,
			 security, or encryption protections of the covered products.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, an element of the intelligence community may not require, or
			 contract with, a manufacturer
			 or developer of covered products to place a mechanism or device into a
			 covered product that would allow  any agency or department of the Federal
			 Government to circumvent any
			 privacy, security, or encryption protections of the covered product.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b/p:2

header.#text: Prohibition on requiring or contracting for installation of devices
Exception for lawful surveillance activities under court order

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall not apply to a lawful surveillance activity conducted
			 pursuant to a court order issued under—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b/p:1
usc-chapter/18/119
usc-chapter/18/121
usc-chapter/18/206
Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978
usc/50/1801/etseq
Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978/s:702

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may bring  a civil action against
			 the United States in a district court of the United States to recover
			 money damages in accordance with
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b
American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:c/p:2

text.#text:
A covered person that suffers an injury proximately
			 caused by a violation of

A court, in awarding money damages to a covered person in a civil action brought under this
			 subsection, shall award—
an amount that is the greater of—
the amount of actual damages; or
reasonable costs, including reasonable attorney's fees.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b

text.#text:
A civil action against the United States under this subsection shall be the exclusive remedy
			 against the United States for a violation of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:c/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
by the agency or department, out of any appropriation,
			 fund, or other account   (excluding any part of such appropriation, fund,
			 or account that is available for the enforcement of any Federal law) that
			 is available for the operating expenses of the agency or department.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Digital Security and Commerce Act of 2014/s:4/ss:b

text.#text:
An agency or department of the United States, including an element of the intelligence community,
			 shall deposit into the general fund of the Treasury of the United States
			 an amount equal to any amount awarded under

The United States shall not be liable to a covered person in a civil action brought under this
			 subsection based on any action taken by an individual acting on behalf of
			 an agency or department of the United States, including an element of the
			 intelligence community, if the individual acted in a good faith reliance
			 on a court order, a grand jury subpoena, or a legislative authorization
			 under—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: usc-chapter/18/119
usc-chapter/18/121
usc-chapter/18/206
Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978
usc/50/1801/etseq
Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978/s:702
